For the last year or more I have been reading the articles in the _Century_ magazine
column2: written by generals and things who served on both the Union and Confederate sides
column3: and have been struck by the number of “decisive battles” that were fought
column4: and the great number of generals who fought them and saved the country. It seems that each general on the Union side
column5: who fought a battle
column6: and writes an article for the aforesaid magazine
column7: admits that his battle was the one which did the business. On the Confederate side
column8: the generals who write articles invariably demonstrate that they everlastingly whipped their opponents
column9: and drove them on in disorder. To read those articles it seems strange that the Union generals who won so many decisive battles
column10: should not have ended the war much sooner than they did
column11: and to read the accounts of battles won by the Confederates
column12: and the demoralization that ensued in the ranks of their opponents
column13: it seems marvellous that the Union army was victorious. Any man who has followed these generals of both sides
column14: in the pages of that magazine
column15: must conclude that the war was a draw game
column16: and that both sides were whipped. Thus far no general has lost a battle on either side
column17: and all of them tacitly admit that the whole thing depended on them
column18: and that other commanders were mere ciphers. This is a kind of history that is going to mix up generations yet unborn in the most hopeless manner.It has seemed to me as though the people of this country had got so mixed up about the matter that it was the duty of some private soldier to write a description of _the_ decisive battle of the war
